messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 65 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Geometric Embeddability of Complexes is ‚àÉ‚Ñù-complete

Paper Abstract: Abstract We show that the decision problem of determining whether a given (abstract simplicial) kùëòk-complex has a geometric embedding in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\mathbb{R}^{d} is complete for the Existential Theory of the Reals for all d‚â•3ùëë3d\geq 3 and k‚àà{d‚àí1,d}ùëòùëë1ùëëk\in\{d-1,d\}. This implies that the problem is polynomial time equivalent to determining whether a polynomial equation system has a real solution. Moreover, this implies NP-hardness and constitutes the first hardness result for the algorithmic problem of geometric embedding (abstract simplicial) complexes.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 65 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 65"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Who Needs Crossings? Hardness of Plane Graph Rigidity",
        "Covering Polygons is Even Harder",
        "The art gallery problem is ‚àÉ‚Ñù‚Ñù\\exists\\mathbb{R}-complete",
        "Training Neural Networks is ‚àÉ‚Ñù‚Ñù\\exists\\mathbb{R}-complete",
        "Framework for ER-Completeness of Two-Dimensional Packing Problems",
        "Knots and links in spatial graphs: a survey",
        "A catalog of EXISTS-R-complete decision problems about Nash equilibria in multi-player games",
        "An Alternative Proof that 3-Manifolds Can be Triangulated",
        "On the generation of oriented matroids",
        "A nonpolyhedral triangulated M√∂bius strip",
        "Linear vs. Piecewise-Linear Embeddability of Simplicial complexes",
        "Approximating embeddings of polyhedra in codimension three",
        "Computing all maps into a sphere",
        "Extendability of continuous maps is undecidable",
        "Time computation of homotopy groups and Postnikov systems in fixed dimension",
        "Algorithmic solvability of the lifting-extension problem",
        "Some algebraic and geometric computations in PSPACE",
        "Computational Geometry Column 62",
        "Recognition and complexity of point visibility graphs",
        "Embedding simply connected 2-complexes in 3-space ‚Äì I. A Kuratowski-type characterisation",
        "A history of algebraic and differential topology, 1900-1960",
        "A Universality Theorem for Nested Polytopes",
        "Smoothing the gap between NP and ER",
        "Embeddability of Simplicial Complexes is Undecidable",
        "√úber n-dimensionale Komplexe, die im R2‚Äãn+1subscriptR2ùëõ1\\textrm{R}_{2n+1} absolut selbstverschlungen sind",
        "Van Kampen‚Äôs embedding Obstruction is incomplete for 222-Complexes in ‚Ñù4superscript‚Ñù4\\mathbb{R}^{4}",
        "‚àÉ‚Ñù‚Ñù\\exists\\mathbb{R}-Completeness for Decision Versions of Multi-Player (Symmetric) Nash Equilibria",
        "Imbeddings of simplicial complexes",
        "Polytopes, graphs, and complexes",
        "On the Complexity of Embeddable Simplicial Complexes",
        "Efficient planarity testing",
        "On Whitney‚Äôs theorem on the unique embeddability of 3-connected planar graphs",
        "Polynomial-time homology for simplicial Eilenberg‚ÄìMacLane spaces",
        "The Complexity of Drawing a Graph in a Polygonal Region",
        "Intersection graphs of segments and ‚àÉ‚Ñù‚Ñù\\exists\\mathbb{R}",
        "Embeddability in the 3-sphere is decidable",
        "Hardness of embedding simplicial complexes in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\\mathbb{R}^{d}",
        "Integer realizations of disk and segment graphs",
        "Dimensionstheorie",
        "Embeddability in ‚Ñù3superscript‚Ñù3\\mathbb{R}^{3} is NP-hard",
        "On Classifying Continuous Constraint Satisfaction problems",
        "The universality theorems on the classification problem of configuration varieties and convex polytopes varieties",
        "A note on geometric embeddings of simplicial complexes in a Euclidean space",
        "Realization of Posets",
        "A new proof of the invariance of the homology groups of a complex",
        "On embeddability of joins and their ‚Äôfactors‚Äù'",
        "On the Links of Vertices in Simplicial d-Complexes Embeddable in the Euclidean 2 d-Space",
        "Realization spaces of polytopes",
        "Realization spaces of 4-polytopes are universal",
        "Complexity of some geometric and topological problems",
        "Polyhedral Maps",
        "Obstructions to the imbedding of a complex in a Euclidean space.: I. The first obstruction",
        "A universality theorem for nonnegative matrix factorizations",
        "Stretchability of pseudolines is NP-hard",
        "A short exposition of Salman Parsa‚Äôs theorems on intrinsic linking and non-realizability",
        "Extendability of simplicial maps is undecidable",
        "Invariants of graph drawings in the plane",
        "Realizability of hypergraphs and Ramsey link theory",
        "Hardness of almost embedding simplicial complexes in ‚Ñùdsuperscript‚Ñùùëë\\mathbb{R}^{d}",
        "Embedding products of graphs into Euclidean spaces",
        "Necessary conditions for geometric realizability of simplicial complexes",
        "Realization Problems for Point Configurations and Polyhedral Surfaces",
        "The Product of Nonplanar Complexes does not Imbed in 4-Space",
        "Komplexe in euklidischen R√§umen",
        "Jordan Curve Theorem"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 65 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Geometric Embeddability of Complexes is ‚àÉ‚Ñù-complete, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
